title: ATM Savvy
description: How to get your cash without losing $5 to hidden fees.

content.title: Your Bank's ATM is Free
content.text: The easiest way to get cash is to use an ATM owned by your own bank. For example, if you have a TD account, using a TD machine is free. If you use a different bank's machine, your bank might charge you a 'network fee' ($2-$3) and that bank might charge you a 'convenience fee' ($3+).

content.title: The Exchange Network
content.text: Many credit unions and smaller banks belong to 'THE EXCHANGE Network.' If you see the Exchange logo on the back of your card, you can use any other ATM with that same logo across Canada for freeâ€”no surcharges or extra fees!

content.title: The 'Cash Back' Trick
content.text: If you are at a grocery store or a pharmacy and need cash but can't find your bank's ATM, ask for 'Cash Back' at the checkout. Most stores will add the cash to your total bill and give it to you for free, helping you avoid ATM surcharges entirely.

quiz.question: What is the most expensive way to get cash in Canada?
options: Using a 'white label' ATM in a bar or gas station
Asking for 'Cash Back' at a grocery store
Going inside the bank branch to see a teller
quiz.explanation: Independent 'white label' machines in places like bars or gas stations often charge the highest convenience fees on top of your own bank's network fees.

quiz.question: If your card has 'THE EXCHANGE' logo, where can you withdraw money for free?
options: At any ATM that also displays 'THE EXCHANGE' logo
Nowhere, there is always a fee
quiz.explanation: The Exchange Network allows members of participating banks and credit unions to use each other's ATMs without paying surcharges.
